metadata.title: Big Data in Financial Services | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Financial Services industry to examine Big Data and the technologies employed

all_paragraphs: We already analyze Peta-scales of Big Data and zettabytes will be next (Kaisler et al., 2013).

But what is Big Data? In a nutshell, it is the ability to retain, process, and understand data like never before (Zikopoulos, 2015). Big Data is when you have challenges that cannot be handled by traditional database systems.

Challenges in the context of Volume, Variety, Velocity, Veracity. These can be found in Financial Services. In fact, technology is so integral to banking that financial institutions are now almost indistinguishable from IT companies.

This article looks at the Financial Services industry to examine Big Data and the technologies employed. It further covers ROI, Big Data analytics, regulation, governance, security, and storage as well as obstacles and challenges that have made the industry what it is today.

Many financial services institutions have already begun their Big Data journey by investing in the platforms that compute and store big data. Why? Because there is value in it and finding new forms of value is all about the financial services business.

Big Data customer analytics drives revenue opportunities by looking at spending patterns, credit information, financial situation, and analyzing social media to better understand customer behaviors and patterns.

Big data is also key to core business models of financial service data providing e.g. Bloomberg, Reuters, DataStream, and financial exchanges that quote financial transaction prices and record millions of daily transactions per second for customer analytics use and regulatory compliance requirements (SOX, GDPR).

All this Big Data has to be stored (see NASDAQ case study) as there is always more data than the organization computers can handle, no matter how fast computers get, and no matter how large the organization is, there are always more data sources than organizations know what to do with or how to combine and data has been at rest and streaming for a long time.
Below are graphical representations of the scale and societal impact big data has had on the finance industry.
After intensive group research, big data has been identified in every part of the value chain and some examples are given below with benefits realization (ROI) identified:

● VISA gained competitive advantages through the use of IMC's‘ in-memory computing’ platform and Grid computing in 2011 to analyze Big Data for credit card fraud detection monitoring. Previously only 2% of the transaction data was monitored, now there are 16 different fraud models with different geographic and market segments (Celent, 2013).

● Garanti Bank, Turkey’s 2nd most profitable bank reduced the cost of operations and gained performance improvement with Big Data analytics using IMC of complex real-time data i.e. web, call center, and social media data (Karwacki, 2015).

● BBVA, Spain’s 2nd largest banking group used the big data interaction tool Urban Discovery to detect potential reputational risk and improve employee and customer satisfaction. They also learned how customers feel when analyzing big data which resulted in public relations and media strategy (Evry, 2014).

● Citigroup (4th largest bank in the US) used big data technology Hadoop for customer service, fraud detection, and web analytics (Marr, 2016). According to (Citi report, 2017) financial institutions use big data for interest rates and GDP forecasts.
● Zestfinance uses big data ZAML technology to closely monitor the credit quality of its counterparties and tried to evaluate its overall credit risk exposures (Lippert, 2014).
● BNY Mellon has implemented big data technology through the Pershing NetX360 platform to look at the risk and opportunities for its investors (BNY Mellon report, 2016).

● Bank of America using big data to enhance multi-channel customer relationships and using in the customer journey starting from the website, call center, teller to improve their service level and customer retention (Davenport, 2013).

● Nasdaq uses AWS S3 big data storage technology by providing hundreds of thousands of small files per day to AWS, and then back to the customer in milliseconds for its Market Replay and Data on Demand service to meet customer demands of quick access to historical stock price information, to see the top of book quotes and trade prices at any historic point in time. Traders and brokers also use it to look for missed opportunities or, potentially, unforeseen events. An ideal solution at a low cost (AWS Case Study).
The following case studies explore Big Data Technologies in financial services in more detail.

JP Morgan Chase bank faced the challenges of understanding big data produced by credit card transactions (spending patterns) as well as upscale increment of the number of unstructured and structured datasets.

They chose Hadoop (open-source framework) to leverage big data analytics to analyze customer spending and earning patterns. Hadoop now assists in data mining unstructured data (e.g. emails, Facebook, or Twitter hashtags) in a way that conventional databases couldn’t do.

With big data analytics, it could identify the best products that best suit their customers i.e. get the right product to the right customer just as they need them on demand. The bank, therefore, chose Hadoop to support the growing size of data and the need for fast processing of complex unstructured data.

Similarly, (Pramanick, 2013) asserts that big data is used by financial organizations to analyze their call center by analyzing unstructured voice recordings for sentiment analysis and this helps them reduce customer churn rate and cross-sell new products to customers.

Deutsche bank chose to use numerous big data platforms and technologies for example to build risk platforms, where unstructured data is mined and processed into a comprehendible and presentable format for Deutsche’s data science experts to draw insight and inspiration for analytical activities. Big data technology is used on the company’s trading and risk data (collected over 10 years).

The data volume and variety require substantial storage, sorting, and sifting through but with big data technologies eliciting and extracting data can be done quickly and efficiently to improve performance and gain a competitive edge by using a matching algorithm which unearths what a data set is telling them about their sales, satisfaction rates and investment return, therefore, getting a truer meaning and deeper perspective in their numbers.

(Sagiroglu et al., 2013) also sites financial firm’s use of automated personalized recommendation algorithms to improve customer intimacy. Therefore, identifying customer needs and delivering tailored messages is advantageous for financial institutions.

Big Data assists identify legitimate versus fraudulent transactions (Money Laundering, stolen credit cards) and predict loan defaults by setting the following parameters payment behavior, interaction history of a borrower with touchpoints of the bank, credit bureaus information, social media activities, and other external public information. (Economic Intelligence, 2014)

The bank used Hadoop for managing unstructured data in 2013 but was skeptical about integration with legacy data systems due to multiple data sources and streams, huge legacy IBM mainframes and repositories worth millions of pounds, and the requirement match the capabilities of both their legacy systems and newer data technology and streamline it.

In the end, a mix of Hadoop, NoSQL, and predictive analytics of big data has accommodated all its operations areas, and technology is now seen as vital in the act of Deutsche’s decision making and strategic management.

All financial transaction exchanges have big data issues and NASDAQ is no exception. Valued at $7.9 trillion, with millions of transactions per second and a world record of 2.9 billion shares traded in one day (in the year 2000), capacity-related delays are a big issue e.g. processing of 6.5 million quotes caused processing delays due to the vast amounts of data being processed (Greene, 2017).

In 2014, the issue was compounded as the business strategy was to move away from being a predominantly US equities exchange to be a global provider of corporate, trading, and technology and information solutions. This meant more data processing and storage of enormous amounts of data content they were legally required to hold.

Companies in the financial services industry are typically required to retain trading information for seven years- a regulatory requirement, which can result in huge storage bills. At NASDAQ, they had a legacy warehouse ($1.16m annual maintenance) and limited capacity (i.e. only 1 year of data online).

Their big data volume consisted of 4–8 billion rows of data inserted per trading day. The data make-up was orders, Trades, Quotes, Market Data, Security Master, and Member Membership data (i.e. structured data). The data warehouse was used to analyze market share, client activity, surveillance, and billing.
There was also a Performance challenge. NASDAQ could not afford to be loading yesterday’s data when clients are running queries. Disaster recovery was another important factor for NASDAQ.

The original scope of requirements was to replace on-premise warehouse with migration to AWS Redshift, keeping equivalent schemas and data, and that the big data solution must satisfy the 2 most important factors for consideration- security and regulatory requirements. The approach was to pull data from numerous sources, validate data i.e. data cleansing and securely load into AWS Redshift.

To detail further, validation of data required alerts to bad/missing data daily, ingestion must enforce data constraints i.e. no dupes, and be fast and security to be paramount for sensitive transactional and company data. This initially caused an issue as AWS Redshift does not enforce data constraints. If there are dupes, it accepts it.

Data is fundamental to their business and dealing with sensitive data means security requirements for Nasdaq are high as they are a regulated company and have to answer to SEC (the US Securities and Exchange Commission).

Therefore they need to have systems that are secure as one of the big challenges of big data is that it will make personal financial information far more distributed and therefore easier to steal. AWS Redshift met security requirements by providing multiple layers of security:
The benefits realization of this migration project completed on schedule with the following benefits:
● Redshift costs were 43% of legacy data warehouse budget (for the same data set circa 1100 tables)
● High watermark= 14b rows in a day
● Best write rate circa 2.76m rows/second
● Queries now running faster than on legacy systems.
● The data storage load increased to over 1200 tables.
● Passed security audits. Internal controls; information security, internal audit, Nasdaq Risk Committee. External audits; SOX, SEC.
● Disaster recovery was resolved by Redshift by having data replicated in multiple data centers.

The current data storage demands for NASDAQ (2014) = 450 GB/day (after compression) loaded into Redshift. Prior compression average i.e. uncompressed= 1,895 GB/day. Clusters are resized once a quarter to meet demand. NDW (Nasdaq Data Warehouse) is currently growing 3 fold every quarter!

NASDAQ’s other issue was scalability without undermining performance and cost. NASDAQ found that the infrastructure required for Apache Hadoop and big data analytics can be difficult to manage and scale. All these past different technologies did not play well together and the cost to manage all these was difficult.

It, therefore, used cloud virtualization to remove hardware limitations, reduced software infrastructure software complexity, cost, and time to deploy Hadoop and Spark. Virtualization simplified the amount of technology and resource needed, maximized processor utilization (18–20% to 80–90%), security was maintained, and performance increased by 2% through virtualization.

From an engineering and operational perspective, NASDAQ was able to meet customer big data analytic needs without having to increase staff numbers. Blue data, therefore, helped NASDAQ drive innovation (Greene, 2017).

GDPR (effective 25 May 2018): (Zerlang, 2017) confirms that transparency on data handling is core to GDPR. Cross-border financial services must record all the conversations for a minimum of 5 years or can be fined e.g. Barclays fined £2.45m for incorrectly reporting on 57.5 million transactions. Similarly, (Gilford, 2016) states that GDPR may fine Tesco Bank £1.9 billion for a data security breach.

Current compliance processes must be reviewed by the financial institutions. Customer consented data can only be used for the consented purpose which means that any historic big data analytics example customer credit card spending data must be destroyed. Billions of dollars’ worth of information will be lost. Therefore, financial institutions should re-look at the process of collecting data.
Predictive modeling techniques in the future must be non-discriminating. Financial institutions must rework their algorithm and automation processes according to new GDPR guidelines.

(Lahiri, 2017) states GDPR will modernize European data protection rules and a violation will be costly; 20 million euros or 4% of the turnover. (LeRoux, 2017) claims that GDPR's new regulation will be the killer of big data. (Woodie, 2017) confirms that GDPR's new amendments will make mandatory data handling processes, transparency regarding usage, and consumer-friendly privacy rules for the 743 million consumers in the EU.

Data Privacy about sharing classified information leads to legal and commercial risk (Deutsche, 2014). Also, cross-linking heterogeneous data for re-identification of the individual is a privacy concern (Fhom, 2015). Therefore, the improper use of such sensitive data could have legal complications.

A skilled workforce to interpret big data in high volume is also a big challenge because wrongly predicted outcomes could be very costly. Trained employees for big data technology is therefore vital as (Fhom, 2015) predicts that there will be a shortage of big data professionals.

So, companies should plan training or hire a new employee before the implementation of big data projects. (McAfee et al., 2012) also advocates strong leadership, good company culture, willingness to adapt to new technology as key ingredients for big data success.

The cost of constructing big data infrastructure is very costly in short term but will be giving a competitive advantage in the long run for the financial firms. Justification of time and money spent on big data (ROI) is not so transparent according to (Davenport, 2013). The firm’s higher management are therefore betting on big data with a long-term strategy.

To conclude, the different cases researched show a wide variety of Big Data technology being used and benefits such as storage reduction as in the case of Nasdaq & AWS RedShift and the resulting benefit storage reduction from 6PB to 500GB.

From these case studies, we have found that the companies investigated all share committed importance and common goal towards the active use of big Data towards their own missions and objective. Between them, there are some commonalities e.g. more targeted marketing, and differences e.g. different types of technology employed for storage.

By analyzing big data, industry players can enhance organizational efficiency, improve customer experience, increase revenue, improve margins, forecast risk better, and can find insight into entering new markets. (Yin et al., 2015) quotes big data improves operational efficiency by 18%.

Similarly, (McAfee et al, 2012) states that companies which are data-driven make an average 5% to 6% more productivity as compared to their competitor in the market. Banks will gain better insight into data quickly for making effective decision making.
● Citi (2017). Searching for Alpha: Big Data. Navigating New Alternative Datasets. Available from https://eaglealpha.com/citi-report/.

● Economist Intelligence Unit (2014). Retail banks and big data: Big data as the key to better risk management. Available from https://www.eiuperspectives.economist.com/sites/default/files/RetailBanksandBigData.pdf.
● Lahiri, K. (2017) GDPR and Brexit: How Leaving the EU Affects UK Data Privacy. Available from https://www.cbronline.com/verticals/cio-agenda/gdpr-brexit-leaving-eu-affects-uk-data-privacy/

● Liu, Z., Yang, P. and Zhang, L., 2013, September. A sketch of big data technologies. In Internet Computing for Engineering and Science (ICICSE), 2013 Seventh International Conference on (pp. 26–29). IEEE.
